required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety Study of DX-88 to Treat Acute Attacks of Hereditary Angioedema (HAE)
clinical_study.official_title: A Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study (72 Patients, Randomized 1:1) Followed by a Repeat-dosing Phase to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of DX-88 (Ecallantide; Recombinant Plasma Kallikrein Inhibitor) for the Treatment of Acute Attacks of Hereditary Angioedema

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if a subcutaneous dose of DX-88 (ecallantide; an investigational product) is safe and relieves symptoms of HAE in patients suffering from moderate to severe acute attacks of HAE.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Treatment Outcome Score at 4 Hours Post-Dose
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Outcome Score (TOS) is a validated, comprehensive measure of symptom response to treatment. At 4 hours , patient assessment of response characterized by their change from baseline in symptom severity and collected by anatomic site of attack involvement, was recorded on a categorical scale (significant improvement [100] to significant worsening [-100]). The response at each anatomic site was weighted by baseline severity and then the weighted scores across all involved sites were averaged to calculate the TOS. Clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a TOS of 30 or higher.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) Score at 4 Hours Post-dose
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) score is a validated, comprehensive point-in-time measure of symptom severity. At baseline and 4 hours, patients rated the severity on a categorical scale (0 = normal, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe) for symptoms at each affected anatomical location. Ratings were averaged to obtain the MSCS score. A decrease in MSCS score reflected an improvement in symptoms; clinically meaningful improvement (minimally important difference) was indicated by a reduction in the score of 0.30 or more.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response
secondary_outcome.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline. Patients were asked "overall how are you feeling" compared to how they felt before study drug. Answer options were "a lot worse", "a little worse", "same", "a little better" or "a lot better or resolved". Significant improvement was the first time that the patient responded to the assessment as "a little better or resolved".

other_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Symptom Complexes of Treated Attack at Baseline(DOUBLE-BLIND PART)
other_outcome.description: Patient-reported severity of symptom complexes at baseline, by symptom complex and treatment group. Patients were to have at least one symptom complex that was moderate or severe. Patients could present with multiple symptom complexes, some of which could be mild. Mild=noticeable but do not impact daily living activities; Moderate=treatment or intervention is highly desirable and activities of daily living are impacted; Severe=require treatment or intervention due to inability to perform activities of daily living. The results are for number of patients with symptom complexes including mild, moderate and severe, provided the patients have at least one symptom complex that was moderate or severe

other_outcome.measure: Treatment Outcome Score at 4 Hours Post-Dose Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
other_outcome.description: Treatment Outcome Score (TOS) is a validated, comprehensive measure of symptom response to treatment. At 4 hours , patient assessment of response characterized by their change from baseline in symptom severity and collected by anatomic site of attack involvement, was recorded on a categorical scale (significant improvement [100] to significant worsening [-100]). The response at each anatomic site was weighted by baseline severity and then the weighted scores across all involved sites were averaged to calculate the TOS. Clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a TOS of 30 or higher.

other_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) Score at 4 Hours Post-dose Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
other_outcome.description: The Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) score is a validated, comprehensive point-in-time measure of symptom severity. At baseline and 4 hours, patients rated the severity on a categorical scale (0 = normal, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe) for symptoms at each affected anatomical location. Ratings were averaged to obtain the MSCS score. A decrease in MSCS score reflected an improvement in symptoms; clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a reduction in the score of 0.30 or more.

other_outcome.measure: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
other_outcome.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline (ie,immediately before treatment) using the following 5-category scale from significant improvement (Score = 100)to significant worsening (Score = -100)

arm_group.description: DX-88 (ecallantide) 30 mg given as three 10 mg/mL subcutaneous injections.
Phosphate Buffer Saline (PBS), pH 7.0 given as 3 subcutaneous injections.

intervention.description: dose of 30 mg (10 mg/ml) given as 3 subcutaneous injections.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 10 and older
- Documented diagnosis of HAE, Type I or II
- Executed informed consent
- Presentation for treatment within 8 hours of patient recognition of moderate to severe HAE attack
Exclusion Criteria:
- Receipt of investigational drug or device, other than DX-88, within 30 days of treatment
- Receipt of non-investigational C1-INH (C1 esterase inhibitor) within 7 days of treatment
- Diagnostic of acquired angioedema, estrogen-dependent angioedema or drug induced angioedema
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Patients who have received DX-88 within 7 days of presentation for dosing in the Double-blind Phase

responsible_party.name_title: Bill Pullman, MD, PhD, Executive Vice President, Chief Development Officer

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients were screened in advance of presenting with an Hereditary Angioedema (HAE) attack but were randomized only upon attack.

group.title: Ecallantide / Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part and eligible for treatment with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part of the study once their Follow-up Visit 1 (Day 7) in the double-blind part was completed.

group.title: Placebo / Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part and eligible for treatment with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part of the study once their Follow-up Visit 1 (Day 7) in the double-blind part was completed.

group.title: Ecallantide (Repeat Dose Only)
group.description: Patients not treated in the double-blind part but treated with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part.

participants_list.participants: One patient was randomized to receive ecallantide but was treated with placebo.
One patient was randomized to receive placebo but was treated with ecallantide.
Not all patients treated in the double-blind part came for treatment in the repeat-dose part.
Not all patients treated in the double-blind part came for treatment in the repeat-dose part.
This arm represents new patients, not treated in the double-blind part of the study.
Some patients participated in only the double-blind or the open label phase.

group.title: Ecallantide / Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part (ITT as treated) and eligible for treatment with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part of the study once their Follow-up Visit 1 (Day 7) in the double-blind part was completed.

group.title: Placebo / Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part (ITT as treated) and eligible for treatment with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part of the study once their Follow-up Visit 1 (Day 7) in the double-blind part was completed.

group.title: Ecallantide (Repeat-Dosing Part Only)
group.description: Patients not treated in the double-blind part but treated with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part. One patient was omitted from analysis in the intent-to-treat and per-protocol populations due to the loss of the data for the 4-hour post-dose assessments during treatment episode 1.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Treatment Outcome Score at 4 Hours Post-Dose
outcome.description: Treatment Outcome Score (TOS) is a validated, comprehensive measure of symptom response to treatment. At 4 hours , patient assessment of response characterized by their change from baseline in symptom severity and collected by anatomic site of attack involvement, was recorded on a categorical scale (significant improvement [100] to significant worsening [-100]). The response at each anatomic site was weighted by baseline severity and then the weighted scores across all involved sites were averaged to calculate the TOS. Clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a TOS of 30 or higher.
outcome.population: ITT as treated: two patients randomized on the same day at the same study center were administered treatment opposite to their randomized treatment assignment. Data were analyzed based on actual treatment received. Imputation was used to account for emerging symptoms and medical intervention. Best possible score = 100; worst possible score = -100.

group.title: Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part.

measure.title: Treatment Outcome Score at 4 Hours Post-Dose
measure.description: Treatment Outcome Score (TOS) is a validated, comprehensive measure of symptom response to treatment. At 4 hours , patient assessment of response characterized by their change from baseline in symptom severity and collected by anatomic site of attack involvement, was recorded on a categorical scale (significant improvement [100] to significant worsening [-100]). The response at each anatomic site was weighted by baseline severity and then the weighted scores across all involved sites were averaged to calculate the TOS. Clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a TOS of 30 or higher.
measure.population: ITT as treated: two patients randomized on the same day at the same study center were administered treatment opposite to their randomized treatment assignment. Data were analyzed based on actual treatment received. Imputation was used to account for emerging symptoms and medical intervention. Best possible score = 100; worst possible score = -100.

analysis.groups_desc: The primary efficacy analysis compared the TOS at 4 hours post-dosing for patients treated with ecallantide and placebo. Treatment effect was assessed by the non-parametric Wilcoxon Rank Sum test because of an assumed non-normal distribution.
analysis.p_value_desc: no adjustment was made for multiple comparisons. Treatment effect will be deemed statistically significant if the coefficient for the treatment group within the statistical model is significant at level 0.05.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) Score at 4 Hours Post-dose
outcome.description: Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) score is a validated, comprehensive point-in-time measure of symptom severity. At baseline and 4 hours, patients rated the severity on a categorical scale (0 = normal, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe) for symptoms at each affected anatomical location. Ratings were averaged to obtain the MSCS score. A decrease in MSCS score reflected an improvement in symptoms; clinically meaningful improvement (minimally important difference) was indicated by a reduction in the score of 0.30 or more.
outcome.population: ITT as treated: two patients randomized on the same day at the same center were administered treatment opposite to their randomized treatment assignments. Data were analyzed based on their actual treatment received. Imputation was used to account for emerging symptoms and medical intervention. Best possible score = 0.0; worst possible score = 3.0.

group.title: Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) Score at 4 Hours Post-dose
measure.description: Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) score is a validated, comprehensive point-in-time measure of symptom severity. measure.population: ITT as treated: two patients randomized on the same day at the same center were administered treatment opposite to their randomized treatment assignments. Data were analyzed based on their actual treatment received. Imputation was used to account for emerging symptoms and medical intervention. Best possible score = 0.0; worst possible score = 3.0.

class.title: Change from baseline in MSCS at 4 hours post-dose

analysis.groups_desc: The analysis compared the change from baseline in MSCS score at 4 hours post-dosing for patients treated with ecallantide and placebo. Treatment effect was assessed by the non-parametric Wilcoxon Rank Sum test because of an assumed non-normal distribution.
analysis.p_value_desc: No adjustment was made for multiple comparisons. Treatment effect will be deemed statistically significant if the coefficient for the treatment group within the statistical model is significant at level 0.05.

Mild=noticeable but do not impact daily living activities; Moderate=treatment or intervention is highly desirable and activities of daily living are impacted; Severe=require treatment or intervention due to inability to perform activities of daily living. The results are for number of patients with symptom complexes including mild, moderate and severe, provided the patients have at least one symptom complex that was moderate or severe

group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part.

group.title: Placebo

outcome.title: Treatment Outcome Score at 4 Hours Post-Dose Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
outcome.description: Treatment Outcome Score (TOS) is a validated, comprehensive measure of symptom response to treatment. At 4 hours , patient assessment of response characterized by their change from baseline in symptom severity and collected by anatomic site of attack involvement, was recorded on a categorical scale (significant improvement [100] to significant worsening [-100]). The response at each anatomic site was weighted by baseline severity and then the weighted scores across all involved sites were averaged to calculate the TOS. Clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a TOS of 30 or higher.
outcome.population: Treatment episode 1 contains data only from those participants who were new patients in the repeat-dosing part. Treatment episode 2 and beyond contain data pooled from patients treated in the double-blind part (ecallantide or placebo) and the repeat-dosing part. Data imputation was used to account for emerging symptoms and medical intervention.

group.title: Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the repeat-dose part.

group.title: Ecallantide

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) Score at 4 Hours Post-dose Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
measure.description: The Mean Symptom Complex Severity (MSCS) score is a validated, comprehensive point-in-time measure of symptom severity. At baseline and 4 hours, patients rated the severity on a categorical scale (0 = normal, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe) for symptoms at each affected anatomical location. Ratings were averaged to obtain the MSCS score. A decrease in MSCS score reflected an improvement in symptoms; clinically meaningful improvement was indicated by a reduction in the score of 0.30 or more.

outcome.title: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response
outcome.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline. Patients were asked "overall how are you feeling" compared to how they felt before study drug. Answer options were "a lot worse", "a little worse", "same", "a little better" or "a lot better or resolved". Significant improvement was the first time that the patient responded to the assessment as "a little better or resolved".
outcome.population: ITT as treated. Patients not reporting significant improvement before 4 hours were censored at 4 hours. Patients receiving additional HAE therapy within 4 hours were censored at the time of the medical intervention. The time to significant improvement is not provided in this display as the median time for placebo was not reached by 4 hours.

group.title: Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part.

measure.title: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response
measure.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline. Patients were asked "overall how are you feeling" compared to how they felt before study drug. Answer options were "a lot worse", "a little worse", "same", "a little better" or "a lot better or resolved". Significant improvement was the first time that the patient responded to the assessment as "a little better or resolved".
measure.population: ITT as treated. Patients not reporting significant improvement before 4 hours were censored at 4 hours. Patients receiving additional HAE therapy within 4 hours were censored at the time of the medical intervention. The time to significant improvement is not provided in this display as the median time for placebo was not reached by 4 hours.

analysis.groups_desc: The Log-Rank test was used to compare the time distribution between the two treatment groups.
analysis.p_value_desc: No adjustment was made for multiple comparisons. Treatment effect will be deemed statistically significant if the coefficient for the treatment group within the statistical model is significant at level 0.05.

outcome.title: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
outcome.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline (ie,immediately before treatment) using the following 5-category scale from significant improvement (Score = 100)to significant worsening (Score = -100)
outcome.population: Patients not reporting significant improvement before 4 hours were censored at 4 hours. Patients receiving additional HAE therapy within 4 hours were censored at the time of the medical intervention. The time to significant improvement is not provided in this display as the interquartile range (IQR) was not reached by 4 hours for most episodes.

group.title: Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the repeat-dose part.

measure.title: Time to Significant Improvement in Overall Response Over Multiple Treatment Episodes
measure.description: The overall response assessment is a patient-reported assessment of global response to therapy. Patients are asked to perform an overall response assessment at regular intervals, relative to baseline (ie,immediately before treatment) using the following 5-category scale from significant improvement (Score = 100)to significant worsening (Score = -100)
measure.population: Patients not reporting significant improvement before 4 hours were censored at 4 hours. Patients receiving additional HAE therapy within 4 hours were censored at the time of the medical intervention. The time to significant improvement is not provided in this display as the interquartile range (IQR) was not reached by 4 hours for most episodes.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were reported from enrollment (Study Day 1) through the conclusion of the Follow-up Visit 2 (Study Days 23-37) of each episode.
reported_events.desc: Additionally, AEs suspected to be related to study procedures were collected from the time of informed consent through enrollment and from Follow-up Visit 2 through Follow-up Visit 3 (Study Days 83-97).

group.title: Double Blind - Ecallantide
group.description: Patients treated with ecallantide in the double-blind part only.

group.title: Double-Blind Placebo
group.description: Patients treated with placebo in the double-blind part only.

group.title: Repeat-Dosing Ecallantide
group.description: All patients treated with ecallantide in the repeat-dosing part, regardless of whether they were treated previously in the double-blind part or not. All adverse events reported in all repeat-dosing episodes are included. Patients reporting more than 1 AE with the same preferred term are counted only once for that preferred term.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Dyax agreements vary, but Dyax will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Dyax reviews publications prior to public release and can request deferral by up to 60 days beyond the proposed publication date if necessary to preserve its intellectual property. Dyax can request changes to publications to remove non-study-related confidential information. Dyax can also request deferral of single-center publications until after disclosure of the clinical trials primary publication.
